questions.text: Which of the following organisms is most sensitive to penicillin?
questions.solution:
Among the given organisms, Treponema pallidum is most sensitive to penicillin. Penicillin G remains the drug of choice for the treatment of syphilis.

Staphylococcus, Streptococcus, and Pneumococcus have developed variable resistance to penicillin G and penicillin G is no longer considered the drug of choice for most of the infections caused by them.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about penicillin-binding proteins is false?

choices.text: Present within cell membrane of bacteria
Mutation in the PBPs gives rise to resistance
PBPs are involved in protein synthesis

questions.solution:
The targets for the action of β-lactam antibiotics are collectively termed penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs)  and they are not involved in protein synthesis.

Transpeptidase enzyme and related proteins constitute the penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) which are present in the bacterial cell membrane. Transpepetidase is involved in the synthesis of peptidoglycan of the bacterial cell wall. All β-lactam groups of antibiotics bind to PBPs and inhibit the last step in peptidoglycan synthesis.

Mutation in the different PBPs confers resistance to the bacteria against the beta-lactams. Methicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) occurs due to alteration in the PBPs.

Imipenem targets the PBPs, disrupting cell wall synthesis and causing death of the micro-organism.

Beta-lactam group of antibiotics include:

  • Penicillins
  • Cephalosporins
  • Carbapenems
  • Monobactam

questions.text: In which of the following patients is penicillin G is not used as treatment?
questions.solution:
Penicillin G is not used against rickettsial infections like scrub typhus, and tetracyclines are the drug of choice in this condition.

Penicillins are ineffective against amebae, plasmodia, rickettsiae, fungi or viruses. 

Uses of penicillin are:

  • Prophylaxis of rheumatic carditis (benzathine penicillin)
  • Syphilis
  • Leptospirosis
  • Cervicofacial actinomycosis
  • Rat-bite fever
  • Meningococcal meningitis
  • Anthrax
  • Listeria

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is Penicillin G not the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Penicillin G is not the drug of choice for Lyme disease, but is an alternative to doxycycline, amoxixilline and cefuroxime in the treatment of Lyme disease. 

Penicillin G is the drug of choice for all forms of actinomycosis, syphilis and rat-bite fever.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about penicillins?

choices.text: Benzathine penicillin is short acting penicillin
Cloxacillin is beta lactamase and acid resistant
Ampicillin is not resistant to beta lactamases

questions.solution:
Benzathine penicillin G and procaine penicillin G are repository preparations of penicillin G and are long-acting.

They are given as deep I.M. injection. Benzathine penicillin has the longest half-life and is administered every 2-4 weeks.

Penicillin V is an acid-resistant penicillin preparation that is administered orally.

Ampicillin has an extended spectrum but is not resistant to beta-lactamases.

Penicillinase-resistant penicillins are:

  • Cloxacillin
  • Dicloxacillin
  • Flucloxacillin
  • Methicillin
  • Nafcillin

questions.text: A patient is prescribed probenecid along with penicillin. What is the rationale behind this?

choices.text: It is a beta lactamase inhibitor
It increases the duration of action of penicillins
It increases the excretion of penicillins in kidney
It decreases the metabolism of penicllins in liver

questions.solution:
Probenecid is used along with penicillin because it increases the duration of action of penicillin.

Penicillin is excreted by tubular secretion in the kidney. Probenecid is a uricosuric drug used in gout that competes with the same transporter (OATP: organic anion transporter) used by penicillin for tubular secretion. Therefore, it decreases the rate of excretion and increases the duration of action of penicillin.

questions.text: The culture and sensitivity report from a wound swab is positive for penicillinase-producing Staphylococcus aureus. Which of the following antimicrobials can be administered?
questions.solution:
The drug that can be used here is cloxacillin since it is not penicillinase susceptible. It is penicillinase-resistant penicillin.

Bacteria can inactivate β-lactam antibiotics by the action of the β-lactamase enzyme. The β-lactamases enzyme activity can be narrow or broad spectrum. In general, gram-positive bacteria produce and secrete a large amount of β-lactamase. Most of these enzymes are penicillinases.

Penicillinase-resistant penicillins are:

  • Cloxacillin
  • Dicloxacillin
  • Flucloxacillin
  • Methicillin
  • Nafcillin

Option B: Penicillin G encompasses the natural preparations and salts of penicillin. They have a narrow spectrum and are susceptible to penicillinase.

Options A and C: Amoxicillin and piperacillin are extended-spectrum penicillins but are susceptible to penicillinase.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an extended spectrum penicillin?
questions.solution:
Cloxacillin is not extended-spectrum penicillin. It is penicillinase-resistant penicillin.

Extended-spectrum penicillins have greater activity than penicillin against gram-negative bacteria because of their enhanced ability to penetrate the Gram-negative outer membrane.

Extended-spectrum penicillins are:

  • Aminopenicillins - ampicillin, amoxicillin
  • Carboxypenicillins - carbenicillin, ticarcillin
  • Ureidopenicillins - piperacillin, mezlocillin

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presented with dysuria and high-grade fever. Urine culture sensitivity shows the growth of carbenicillin-sensitive E. coli. Which of the following is true about the antibiotic?

choices.text: Has no effect in Proteus infection

questions.solution:
Carbenicillin is effective in Pseudomonas infection.

It is extended-spectrum penicillin belonging to the carboxypenicillins group. It has activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and indole-positive Proteus. It is acid labile and is not administered orally. 

Antipseudomonal penicillins are:

  • Carboxypenicillins - carbenicillin, ticarcillin
  • Ureidopenicillins - mezlocillin, piperacillin

questions.text: Which among the following is not a beta-lactamase enzyme inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Piperacillin is not a beta-lactamase enzyme inhibitor. It is an extended-spectrum beta-lactam (ureidopenicillin) drug having significant antipseudomonal action.

Beta-lactamases are a family of enzymes produced by many gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria that inactivate beta-lactam antibiotics by opening the beta-lactam ring. 

Beta-lactamase inhibitors available for clinical use are:

  • Clavulanic acid
  • Sulbactam
  • Tazobactam
  • Avibactam

questions.text: Which of the following antimicrobials is effective against an organism producing extended-spectrum beta-lactamases?
questions.solution:
Piperacillin-tazobactam is an antimicrobial that is effective against organisms producing extended-spectrum beta-lactamases.

Extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) enzyme produced by bacteria causes resistance to most of the penicillins, cephalosporins (third and fourth generation), and monobactams. ESBL is most prevalent among gram-negative organisms like Klebsiella and E. coli.

ESBL can be inhibited by combining beta-lactamase inhibitors like clavulanic acid or tazobactam. Carbapenems and quinolones have inherent activity against ESBL.

Note: As piperacillin has greater activity against Klebsiella and other gram-negative organisms than amoxicillin, piperacillin-tazobactam can be considered as a better option in this question.

questions.text: Which of the following is an acid-susceptible penicillin?
questions.solution:
Methicillin and nafcillin are penicillinase-resistant penicillins that are acid susceptible and are administered parenterally.

Methicillin use is associated with higher incidence of interstitial nephritis.

Ampicillin, amoxicillin and cloxacillin are acid-resistant penicillins.

Related Pearl: Acid resistant penicillins: mnemonic "VODKA"

The mnemonic "VODKA" can be used to for acid-resistant penicillins that are active orally.

  • V - Penicillin V
  • O - Oxacillin
  • D - Dicloxacillin
  • K - Cloxacillin
  • A - Amoxycillin/ Ampicillin

questions.text: A patient who is being treated with an antimicrobial agent presents with neutropenia. Which of the following drugs could be the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Neutropenia is seen with nafcillin. It is penicillinase-resistant parenteral penicillin.

It is associated with side effects like neutropenia and interstitial nephritis. In patients with renal failure, it is associated with seizures.

Methicillin is also a penicillinase-resistant penicillin. Its use is associated with a higher incidence of interstitial nephritis than other penicillins, hence it is no longer used.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man undergoing treatment with penicillin presents with fever, myalgia, and exacerbation of pre-existing cutaneous lesions. Which of the following diseases is he most probably being treated for?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction and it is associated with the use of penicillin in syphilis.

Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is a host immune reaction due to the release of spirochetal antigen by the dying T.pallidum in patients on treatment with penicillin. This occurs in primary and most cases of secondary syphilis and is characterized by fever, shivering, myalgia, exacerbation of lesions and vascular collapse. Symptomatic treatment suffices and penicillin treatment need not be interrupted.

questions.text: A patient who is undergoing treatment with antibiotics presents with diarrhea, fever, and leukocytosis. Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea is suspected. This condition is most commonly associated with the use of which of the following group of drugs?
questions.solution:
Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea is mostly due to aminopenicillins.

Antibiotic-associated colitis is caused by Clostridium difficile infection due to the destruction of the normal gut microbial flora by the use of antibiotics. 

Although all antibiotics can cause the condition, the most commonly implicated are:

  • Ampicillin (aminopenicillin)
  • Clindamycin
  • Third-generation cephalosporins
  • Fluoroquinolones.

questions.text: A patient being treated with ampicillin presents with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. C. difficile infection is suspected. Which of the following monoclonal antibodies is approved for use in this patient?
questions.solution:
Bezlotoxumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to Clostridium difficile toxin B, indicated to reduce the recurrence of Clostridium difficile infection (CDI).

Actoxumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to Clostridium difficile toxin A but it is not approved because of lack of efficacy. 

Adalimumab is an anti-TNF alpha antibody used in rheumatoid arthritis and various other conditions.

questions.text: Systemic use of bacitracin is restricted due to:
questions.solution:
The systemic use of bacitracin is restricted due to nephrotoxicity.

Bacitracin is a polypeptide antibiotic and it inhibits the synthesis of the bacterial cell wall.

Currently, it is used topically for dermal infections and for ophthalmic infections. Parenteral use of this antibiotic leads to nephrotoxicity.

questions.text: Daptomycin is not indicated in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Daptomycin is not indicated in community-acquired pneumonia because even though it penetrates adequately into the lung, it is inactivated by pulmonary surfactant and thus is not useful.

Daptomycin is a cyclic lipopeptide antibiotic. It acts by depolarising bacterial membranes resulting in loss of membrane potential and cell death.

Daptomycin is indicated in the following infections:

  • Complicated skin and soft-tissue infections
  • Complicated bacteremia caused by staphylococcus and streptococcus
  • Right-sided endocarditis
  • Vancomycin-resistant enterococcal infections

Its efficacy in the above-mentioned conditions is comparable to that of vancomycin.

questions.text: Polymyxins are effective against:
questions.solution:
Polymyxins are effective against gram-negative bacteria.

Polymyxin group of antibiotics includes polymyxin B and colistin which have their antimicrobial spectrum limited primarily to gram-negative aerobic bacteria. They interact with the phospholipid of the bacterial cell membranes and disrupt it.

Polymyxins are used in various topical formulations. Parenteral formulations are used only in serious systemic infections that are resistant to other antimicrobials. Nephrotoxicity limits widespread systemic use.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of resistance by lactamases​ to β-lactam antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Resistance by lactamases is through the degradation of antibiotics.

The bacterial cell wall is made of heteropolymeric peptidoglycan that confers mechanical stability. The β-lactam antibiotics inhibit the last step in peptidoglycan synthesis by acylating the transpeptidase via cleavage of the –CO–N– bond of the β-lactam ring. These transpeptidase targets are collectively called Penicillin Binding Proteins (PBPs)

Beta-lactamases are enzymes produced by certain bacteria that inactivates β-lactam antibiotics by hydrolysis of the β-lactam ring in their structure.

The resistance to penicillins and other beta-lactam antibiotics can be conferred through one of the four mechanisms:

  1. Inactivation of antibiotic by lactamases
  2. Modification of target PBPs
  3. Impaired penetration of drug to target PBPs
  4. Antibiotic efflux

questions.text: A known asthmatic patient with fever and sore throat was prescribed an antibiotic. Two days later he presents with a maculopapular rash. Which of the following drugs might have caused this?
questions.solution:
Skin rashes of all types may be caused by allergy to penicillin.

Amoxicillin and ampicillin are aminopenicillins. The incidence of skin rashes appears to be highest following the use of ampicillin, at about 9%.

Amoxicillin is a close congener of ampicillin with the following features:

  • Better oral absorption; food does not interfere with the absorption
  • Incidence of diarrhea is less
  • More active against penicillin-resistant pneumococci

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct for a patient on high dose of penicillin and gentamicin?

choices.text: TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects
Both drugs do not need monitoring

questions.solution:
Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that requires therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) as it has a narrow therapeutic index. It is nephrotoxic and ototoxic (predominantly vestibular effects).

The threshold for toxicity for gentamicin is the plasma concentration of 2 μg/mL, the maximum recommended for prolonged exposure.

Aminoglycoside antibiotics act by binding to the 30s ribosome and inhibiting protein synthesis. Their ability to cause misreading of DNA templates and the formation of aberrant proteins that get incorporated into bacterial cell membranes makes them bactericidal agents.

 Common ototoxic drugs are:

  1. Antibiotics - aminoglycosides (gentamicin > tobramycin > amikacin > neomycin), erythromycin, tetracyclines.
  2. Chemotherapeutic agents - cisplatin, bleomycin, nitrogen mustards.
  3. High dose aspirin, acetaminophen, NSAID’s
  4. Antimalarials - quinine, quinidine
  5. Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors - sildenafil

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

The mnemonic "DATLAAT MC" can be used.

  • D: Digoxin
  • A: Anti-arrhythmic
  • T: Theophylline
  • L: Lithium
  • A: Aminoglycosides
  • A: Anti-epileptics
  • T: Tricyclic antidepressants
  • M: Methotrexate
  • C: Calcineurin inhibitors
